original: In the western world, it is customary to openly inform patients about their cancer diagnosis as it fosters a comprehensive understanding of the illness and empowers them to make decisions regarding their treatment, promoting autonomy and control over their lives. However, in the Chinese culture, the practice of withholding cancer diagnosis is common, sparking debates on the necessity to align traditional beliefs with modern advancements. Challenges arise in communicating cancer diagnoses in the Chinese culture due to the reluctance of patients to openly discuss health issues, posing difficulties for family members and healthcare providers. Transparent communication in the western world aids patients in understanding their condition, enabling informed decision-making on treatment options. Conversely, in the Chinese culture, comprehension of medical terminology and treatment choices is often limited, leading to potential inaccuracies in treatment decisions. Emphasizing the importance of patient empowerment, candid discussions about cancer in the western world facilitate patients in taking charge of their health journey. In contrast, the lack of autonomy and loss of control experienced by patients in the Chinese culture highlight the significance of transparent communication to empower patients and ensure their well-being throughout their cancer journey.
